chapter: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the vaginal epithelium?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Columnar cells . Explanation: Layers of vaginal epithelium: Cells Functions Superficial layer It forms the outermost protective barrier, eventually shed from the surface. Intermediate layer Provide structural support to the epithelium and contribute to the thickness and resilience of the vaginal tissue. Parabasal layer Serve as transitional cells between the basal and intermediate layers, reflecting ongoing epithelial turnover and differentiation. Basal layer Mitotically active and serves as the regenerative source for the epithelium. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 991. Organoids of the female reproductive tract PMC(NIH.gov) https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33580825/
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I

questions.question: Which strain of the HPV virus is responsible for causing Condyloma acuminatum?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) HPV 6 and 11. Explanation: Histopathology image suggests Condylomata acuminata, which are benign genital warts caused by low-risk HPV 6 and 11, a double-stranded DNA virus that infects differentiated squamous epithelial cells. It is sexually transmitted and is characterized by multiple, raised, fleshy skin-coloured growths and involves vulvar, vagina, perineal, and perianal regions. Condyloma acuminata are cauliflower-like, dry, and bulky, typically found in the squamous mucosa of the anal canal. Condyloma lata are smooth, moist, and flat, often located in the genital area, inner thighs, axillae, or oral mucosa. Unlike condyloma acuminata, condyloma lata may appear ulcerated. Microscopic examination reveals papillary, exophytic, treelike stromal cores covered by thickened squamous epithelium. Koilocytes are evident, featuring enlarged nuclei, hyperchromasia, and a perinuclear cytoplasmic halo. These are not precancerous lesions, and HPV vaccines provide excellent protection. HPV 16 and 18 (Option B): HPV 16 and 18 are high-risk strains responsible for cervical carcinoma, vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) and vulvar carcinoma.

questions.question: A 25-year-old sexually active female presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge and dysuria. Upon examination of the cervix, the following appearance is noted. Wet mount microscopy reveals the findings shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this presentation?

questions.question: A 58-year-old woman complains of persistent itching and redness in her vulvar area. On examination, well-defined, erythematous plaques with an eczematous appearance are noted. A biopsy reveals large cells with pale cytoplasm and positive staining for mucopolysaccharides. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for cytokeratin 7. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Extramammary Paget's disease Explanation: Biopsy findings commonly reveal large, round cells, known as Paget cells, within the epidermis. These cells have pale cytoplasm containing
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I

questions.question: Which of the following has a strong association with clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina?

options.A: Male partner who has multiple sexual partners
options.D: Sexual activity at a young age

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) In utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol Explanation: The clinical presentation and biopsy findings suggest Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina, characterized histologically by cells with clear cytoplasm and hobnail cells and is strongly associated with in-utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES). Vaginal adenosis (precursor lesion for clear cell adenocarcinoma) refers to the presence of glandular columnar epithelium in the proximal vagina. Diethylstilbestrol is a synthetic non-steroidal estrogen that was historically widely used to prevent potential miscarriages by stimulating the synthesis of estrogen and progesterone in the placenta (especially from the 1940s to the 1970s). Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 994
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of vaginal bleeding and a visible mass protruding from her vagina. On examination, a polypoid mass with a "grape-like" appearance is observed. A biopsy is taken, and immunohistochemical staining is positive for desmin. Which of the following will show as a biopsy finding?

options.A: Cells with small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end
options.B: Marked atypia of cells with numerous keratin pearls
options.D: Fibrous stroma covered by mucus-secreting endocervical glands

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Cells with small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end. Explanation: The clinical presentation and IHC findings suggest Sarcoma botryoides, a rare type of Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, characterised by polypoid,rounded, bulky masses that have the appearance and consistency of grapelike clusters, commonly found in infants and children younger than 5 years of age. Histologically characterised by cells with small and oval nuclei with small protrusions of cytoplasm resembling a tennis racket (Tennis racket cells/ Tadpole cells) and rarely cytosolic striations (indicative of muscle differentiation) can be seen. The "cambium layer" in sarcoma botryoides refers to a band of undifferentiated or slightly differentiated tumour cells beneath the surface epithelium. Its presence aids in diagnosing sarcoma botryoides and distinguishing it from other vaginal tumours. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for Desmin/MyoD1. It tends to invade locally and cause death by penetration into the peritoneal cavity obstruction of the urinary tract.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I

questions.question: Which of the following is an advantage of liquid-based cytology (LBC) over the conventional Pap smear?

options.B: More widely available in resource-limited settings

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Allows simultaneous HPV testing Explanation: Aspect Conventional Cervical Screening (Pap Smear) Liquid-Based Cytology (LBC) Sample Collection Cells are collected using a spatula or brush and smeared directly onto a glass slide. Cells are collected using a brush and then rinsed into a vial containing a preservative solution. Processing Time Typically longer due to manual preparation and staining. Faster automated processing and staining. Sensitivity and Specificity Lower sensitivity and specificity compared to LBC. Higher sensitivity and specificity for detecting abnormalities. Cost Generally lower cost. Higher cost due to specialized equipment and supplies. (Option A) Follow-up Testing Additional sample collection may be needed if the initial sample is inadequate. Usually provides enough samples for additional tests (e.g., HPV testing) without recollection. (Option D) Adequacy of cells 8000-12000 epithelial cells/ 10 hpf (Option C) 5000 epithelial cells/10 hpf Resource limited setting Available in resource-limited settings (Option B) Specialized equipment and infrastructure are needed Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 1000,1001 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6022377/
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD for regular Pap smear screening. The smear suggests a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Which of the following abnormal cell types was most likely seen on the smear?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Koilocytes Explanation: Koilocytes are abnormal cervical cells seen on pap smears, indicative of HPV infections of the cervix. They are squamous epithelial cells with nuclear enlargement, coarse chromatin, perinuclear cavitation, and irregular nuclear membranes. A rim of condensed cytoplasm often surrounds the perinuclear cavitation, giving the cell a "halo" appearance. Doderlein cells (Option A): Doderlein cells are large, glycogen-rich squamous epithelial cells in the vaginal epithelium, associated with Lactobacillus species. A reduction or absence of Doderlein cells can indicate pathological conditions such as bacterial vaginosis. Hobnail cells (Option B): Hobnail cells are found in clear cell carcinoma of the ovary. Arias-Stella reaction cells (Option C): Arias-Stella reaction cells are a type of glandular epithelial cell found in the endometrium during pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy, or pathological conditions like gestational trophoblastic disease.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I

questions.question: Which of the following risk factors is not typically associated with cervical cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Nulliparity Explanation: Nulliparity is not a risk factor for cervical cancer. Nulliparity is a risk factor for breast and ovarian cancer. Risk factors for cervical cancer include: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, particularly High-risk HPVs, is the most important factor in the development of cervical cancer Multiple sexual partners (Option B) or early sexual activity Smoking (Option A) Weak immune system Long-term use of oral contraceptives (OCP) (Option C) High parity Lack of regular cervical screening (Pap tests) Family history of cervical cancer Socioeconomic factors Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 996 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431093/
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman undergoes a routine gynecological examination. Abnormalities are detected on her pap smear, and colposcopy-guided biopsy reveals dysplastic changes involving two-thirds of the cervical epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 2 (CIN2) Explanation: Grade HPE Features CIN 1 Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia with koilocytic atypia showing atypical cells in the lower 1/3rd of the epithelium. CIN 2 High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) with progressive atypia and expansion of the immature basal cells in the lower 2/3rd of the epithelial thickness CIN 3 HSIL with diffuse atypia, loss of maturation, and expansion of the immature basal cells to the entire length of the epithelial surface. Invasive cervical carcinoma (Option D): Invasive cervical carcinoma presents with invasion beyond the basement membrane of the cervical epithelium.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix? HPV types 16 and 18 are the most common HPV types identified in invasive cervical cancer. The most common site of metastasis is the lungs. E6 protein interferes with the activity of the tumor suppressor proteins p53. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histologic subtype.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1,2,3,4 Explanation: Cervical Carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma (80%) and adenocarcinoma (15%) are the main cervical cancer subtypes caused by high-risk HPVs (HPV16 and 18). HPV's E6 and E7 proteins disrupt p53 and Rb tumor suppressors, respectively. Lung metastasis is common and indicates poor prognosis. Squamous cell carcinoma: Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 998-1000 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7414489/
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-I
